subject: what net worth is considered "wealthy"
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread explores the subjective and objective definitions of "wealthy," particularly regarding a $10M net worth, revealing a stark divide between practical financial analysis and deep-seated societal cynicism. Many view the current economic system as rigged, making true financial independence elusive and leading to a pervasive sense of frustration and resentment towards existing power structures.
top_quote:
The short answer is yes, $10,000,000 is rich by any metric. "Wealthy" is a weird word that has other implications.

1. 10m is more than 95% of the population will ever save
2. 10m is 300-400k passive without touching principle - solidly in the top 10% (probably 5) household income. Matches the highest tier wagies - doctors, FAANG, directors.
3. It's enough to retire immediately. In fact, 5 mil is, so it's enough to retire, 10 is enough to retire with some luxuries.
4. Perhaps the key - 10 mill is not "achievable". 3-5 mil maybe is - work the right job, save, invest, get lucky a few times, start a small biz. 10 is beyond what most even dream about.

On the other hand, 10 mil is not enough to throw money around or buy what people think about as true luxuries - no yachts, private flights (reasonably), islands, starting businesses without dedicating life to them, etc.
image_analysis: The image shows a man holding a document titled "The S.W.E.A.T. Pledge," which outlines a cynical, conspiratorial view of a rigged system where "predetermined winners will win," expressing sentiment against societal and economic manipulation.

Spanish is a servant's language. Anyone who speaks French (and there's globally not many of them) and matters also speaks English.. There's a billion Chinese speakers but they're either poor or craving English.

It posits a future where AI liberates high-IQ individuals from menial tasks while rendering the less adaptable irrelevant, transforming work, education, and societal structure dramatically.

subject: Chainlink
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread reveals a deep-seated frustration and psychological struggle among Chainlink (LINK) investors, divided between early adopters who profited immensely and those who are now 'bagholding' due to missed selling opportunities and unfulfilled price targets like '$1000 EOY'. It highlights the painful reality of altcoin investment, where past success can lead to current regret if not managed with timely profit-taking and diversification, contrasted against the performance of other assets like BTC, ETH, gold, and silver.
top_quote:
I won't deny that they weren't some absolute winners, there always are. People who made big buys at ICO prices and selling around the top being a clear example. But a lot of anons got in at .50, at $2, at $10, being told all the way up that LINK was still just getting started. 10k was widely thrown around as the "make it" stack, but if you held a poll virtually no one would consider $500k as "making it".
I think if LINK had just a little more steam back then and made it to $100 there would be far less wailing on /biz/ about it these days, as people were warned ahead of time to have 10k LINK, and if 1M USD wasn't enough for cashing out that's a you problem.
